header.title: The Black Dragon or The Infernal Forces Subjugated by Man
authors: Translated and Edited by Sarah Kane French

central_thesis: The Black Dragon presents itself as a practical manual for a magician to command and subjugate infernal spirits and forces, under divine authority, to achieve various material and immaterial desires, including wealth, protection, influence, healing, and inflicting harm. It emphasizes strict adherence to precise rituals, the use of consecrated tools, and the importance of maintaining spiritual authority over the summoned entities to ensure safety and success.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the purpose of the book as a guide to 'good and evil' and cautions against avarice. It outlines fundamental principles for the operator's safety, emphasizing the protective role of the Circle and the need for a firm will. It also lists 'Fortunate and Unfortunate Days' for operations and details essential tools like the Knife and Fork of the Mysteries, along with preparatory steps like purification and the consecration of charcoal.

This part provides specific conjurations for various demonic entities, including general spirits, the Four Kings (Magoa, Egym, Baymon, Amaymon), and daily spirits associated with each day of the week (Lucifer for Monday, Frimost for Tuesday, Astaroth for Wednesday, Silcharde for Thursday, Bechard for Friday, Guland for Saturday, Surgat for Sunday). It details the use of divine names and threats to compel obedience, along with procedures for dismissing spirits and receiving their 'mark' as a sign of acceptance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part the Second CHARMS AND COUNTER-CHARMS
structure_content.summary: This section offers practical spells and counter-spells for a variety of purposes. Rituals include methods to compel someone who has caused harm to appear, break evil spells on animals, distract a person, inflict suffering, and offer protection against weapons or fire. These often involve specific materials like animal hearts, nails, or toads, combined with precise incantations and actions.

This part delves into more advanced and diverse magical operations. It covers charms for guarding livestock, harming rival flocks, healing sick animals, curing ailments like cancer, recovering stolen objects, obtaining visions of the future, stopping serpents, controlling horses, and various counter-charms. Noteworthy rituals include achieving invisibility using a black cat's bone, charms for tireless travel, gambler's luck, lottery success, and even coercive love spells like making a girl 'dance naked' or 'come to you'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part the Fourth THE HAND OF GLORY and THE BLACK HEN
structure_content.summary: This section details the creation and use of two powerful magical artifacts for material gain. 'The Hand of Glory' is described as a snake-like creature formed from mare's hair, capable of doubling wealth. 'The Black Hen' ritual involves a specific hen and a cypress branch to summon a powerful spirit (depicted as having a dog's head, ass's ears, and horns) who can grant riches and happiness.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part the Fifth ORISONS AND PRAYERS
structure_content.summary: This concluding part provides a collection of prayers essential for the practitioner, including a 'Prayer of Thanksgiving,' a 'Prayer for Protection from Evil Spirits,' the 'Pater Noster,' 'Ave Maria,' 'Le Veni Creator,' and 'I Believe in God.' It also includes 'The Great Invocation to Summon the Spirit with whom one wishes to make a Pact,' specifically naming Lucifer, Belzebuth, and Astaroth to summon Lucifuge Rofocale for a pact of riches.

key_concepts.definition: The primary protective barrier and sacred space for the operator, typically drawn with blessed chalk or charcoal. Within it, the magician is 'king and master,' safe from malign spirits, who are forbidden to enter it.

A crucial magical tool, a small right fork with two blades, crafted from a hazel rod with a purchased steel knife. It is used to compel disobedient spirits by placing its 'teeth' in flame, augmenting their torments.

An item demanded by spirits during a conjuration. The text instructs the operator to provide a minor material item (e.g., a penny) but strictly forbids giving anything from one's own body (hair, blood, handkerchief) and mandates that the spirit must also give a pledge before being dismissed.

A sign of a spirit's 'approval and acceptance' of the Book and the operator's command. It is obtained by throwing a small round of virgin parchment into the Circle for the spirit to mark, which is then affixed to the book's first page.

A ritual act of calling forth and commanding spirits, employing specific divine names, invocations, and threats of infernal torment to force their appearance in human form and compel their obedience to the operator's will.

A double-sided mirror (one accurate, one magnifying) used for counter-charms, revealing the identity of malefactors, and healing various physical ailments by touching the affected area and reciting specific prayers.

A magical item, created from mare's hair, which transforms into a snake-like creature capable of doubling gold or silver placed in its box. Its power and form evolve with the operator's 'planet ascends'.

A consecrated black hen (virgin, never laid an egg) used in a ritual performed at midnight within a cypress circle. Its sacrifice is intended to summon a powerful demon (described as a hybrid creature) who grants riches and happiness.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in 'The Black Dragon' is a form of ceremonial magic focused on the evocation and subjugation of infernal spirits. It operates on the principle that demons can be compelled to obey human commands through the invocation of superior divine authority (Christian names and epithets). The system relies on creating a protected ritual space (the Circle), using consecrated tools, and performing specific conjurations and dismissals. The ultimate goal is to obtain desired outcomes – from wealth and protection to influence and curses – by forcing spirits to perform tasks or reveal information, while ensuring the magician's safety through strict adherence to the prescribed protocols and divine sanction.
tools: Wild Rod of Hazel (approx. three feet long)
Small Right Fork (Fork of the Mysteries, with two notched blades)
Pascal Candle or Lamp with burning spirit of brandy
Animal Heart (from a thoroughly dead deer or female cow)
Black Cock (never laid egg or approached by a rooster)
Clay Pipe with Brass Fire Cover
rituals: Making and Consecrating the Protective Circle: Drawing a twelve-foot diameter circle with blessed chalk or charcoal (made from a boxwood cross), inscribing protective phrases like 'I FORBID THEE LUCIFER IN THE NAME OF THE MOST HOLY TRINITY TO ENTER THIS CIRCLE'.
Purification of the Operator: Cleansing hands and body before any philosophical operation.

Conjuration of Demons: Reciting specific lengthy invocations using divine names (e.g., Eloym, Jah, El, Eloy, Tetragrammaton, Jesus) and threats of eternal torment to force spirits (including kings like Magoa, Egym, Baymon, Amaymon, and daily spirits like Lucifer, Astaroth) to appear in 'attractive human form' and obey commands.
Dismissal of Spirits: Rituals to send evoked spirits back, ensuring 'peace' and their readiness for future calls, typically involving showing the Pentacle and stating a sentence of return.

Operation of the Sign: After a spirit's appearance and injunction, throwing a virgin parchment into the Circle for the spirit to mark, symbolizing its approval and acceptance, to be affixed to the book's first page.

To Make One Who Has Done You Evil Come: Pricking a dead animal's heart (deer or female cow) with nine hawthorne prickles or new nails, reciting specific incantations ('Adibaga, Sabaoth, Adonay, contra ratout prisons pererunt fini unixio oaracle gossum'), performing a Novena, and then burning the heart to compel the malefactor to appear and ask for grace.

To Render Invisible: Stealing a black cat, boiling it for 24 hours, and using a specific bone placed between the teeth while gazing into a mirror and reciting 'Pater, in manus tuas, commendo spiritem meum' until invisibility is achieved.

To Gain at All Times at the Lottery: Reciting a specific Orison ('Domine Jesus-Criste...') three times, then writing the Orison on a virgin parchment (consecrated with a Mass of the Holy Spirit) and placing it under one's ear while sleeping to receive guidance from genii of one's planet.

To Make a Girl Come to You (Love Spell): Writing the girl's name and a sigil (Fig 16) on virgin parchment, placing it on the ground, kneeling with the right foot on it, looking at the highest star, holding a white wax candle, and reciting a conjuration ('O beautiful Moon, O most beautiful star...') three times to torment and obsess the target until she comes.

To Make a Girl Dance Naked (Coercive Love Spell): Writing a sigil (Fig 17) with bat's blood on virgin parchment, placing it upon a blessed altar stone where a mass is said, then placing it under the sill of a door the target must pass through to make her undress and dance frantically until death or removal of the sigil.

To Summon the Spirit with Whom One Wishes to Make a Pact: A 'Great Invocation' directed to Lucifer, Belzebuth, and Astaroth, commanding Lucifuge Rofocale to appear in human guise without foul odors to make a pact for riches, under threat of eternal torment using Solomon's Clavicle's powerful words.

relevant_quotes.text: Never lose sight of the fact that the aforementioned Circle is your safeguard: while you are within it, in it's interior, you are king and master, while outside, you would be at the power of the malign spirit.
Never agree to give him an object from your body, hair or blood, etc. Neither give him your handkerchief, of which you have used yourself, as it will contain substances of your body.
If you do not obey me promptly and without delay, I will augment your pain and suffering in Hell for a thousand years; I, thus, force you here, to appear in attractive human form...
Remember only that avarice is always punished and virtue is always rewarded, and that any pact signed of your blood puts you at the orders of Satan.
The spirit will never come without being called by your heart as well as your mouth, which proves, once more, for you to be firm in your will.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is a classic example of a grimoire from the Western Esoteric tradition, closely aligning with the 'Black Magic' category, specifically belonging to the family of the 'Grand Grimoire' or 'Red Dragon' (Le Dragon Rouge) tradition, as hinted by the title and the inclusion of the 'Great Invocation to Summon the Spirit with whom one wishes to make a Pact' for Lucifuge Rofocale. Its historical relevance lies in its contribution to the grimoire corpus, reflecting 18th-19th century folk magic and ceremonial practices centered on direct demonic invocation and subjugation for material ends. Methodologically, it relies heavily on the authority of Christian divine names (Trinity, Jesus Christ, Mary, Saints) to command infernal entities, a common syncretic approach in many grimoires. The text offers a detailed, step-by-step operative system, distinguishing it from purely theoretical works. It provides a window into the historical understanding of spiritual hierarchies and the perceived means of interacting with them, showcasing a pragmatic, results-oriented approach to magic.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is likely individuals deeply interested in traditional grimoire magic, ceremonial evocation, and the practical application of occult arts for personal gain, protection, or vengeance. This includes serious occult practitioners, scholars of Western Esotericism, and those drawn to the 'forbidden' or 'darker' aspects of magical traditions. The stringent warnings about risks ('malign spirit', 'eternal torment', 'orders of Satan') and the need for a 'firm will' suggest it is not intended for the faint of heart or casual dabblers, but rather for a dedicated, if not desperate, magician willing to engage with infernal forces under prescribed conditions.
